Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Studies of Relativistic Heavy Ions Collisions in ALICE at the LHC
Award.AbstractNarration:
At the core of a successful undergraduate education in STEM disciplines is the capacity to offer students the opportunity to practice scientific inquiry that connects the use of modern technology to captivating areas of research. This grant supports a research program to study Heavy Ion Collisions at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) with the ALICE experiment. The focus of the Heavy Ion program at CERN is to understand the behavior of matter at very high density, corresponding to conditions a fraction of a second after the Big Bang, when a hot, dense medium of quarks and gluons existed. The goal is to recreate these conditions via colliding nuclei at very high energies.

Chicago State University (CSU) will contribute to the ALICE effort by working on two areas of interest: the jet physics capabilities brought to ALICE by the electromagnetic calorimeter (EMCal), and R&D for the upgrade of ALICE's central barrel tracking and trigger detectors. The physics analysis of J/Psi jets detected in the EMCal that is included in the project constitutes a unique program of measurements to investigate the production mechanism of quarkonia in proton-proton collisions and the response of quark gluon medium to jet energy deposition in lead-lead collisions. On the other hand the group's R&D contribution to the upgrade of ALICE will provide opportunities for the involvement of undergraduate students in hardware projects.

Recruiting, retaining, and educating science, technology, engineering and mathematics students and teachers has been identified as the cornerstone in the effort to improve scientific literacy, maintain economic growth, and to provide the platform for relevant scientific discoveries. This project addresses these issues by consolidating a high-energy experimental nuclear physics program at CSU: (1) The use of cutting-edge technology for high-energy nuclear physics experiments provides an attractive opportunity to captivate and prepare students, (2) A collaborative program at an international laboratory exposes students to research experiences they could not otherwise obtain at an undergraduate university. Because of the make-up of the student population, the location of the university and the current outreach programs of the department, this program has the potential to promote inner-city underrepresented students into STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has provided summer research experiences abroad for undergraduate students at Chicago State University.  The ALICE experiment, which is devoted to heavy ion physics, located at the European Center for Nuclear Research (CERN) in Geneva, Switzerland, has been the center of the program.   The program consists of students performing physics analysis using data obtained by the ALICE experiment, and on participating in detector upgrades for the ALICE experiment through hardware development, computer simulations and data analysis. The program is designed such that many of the students continue the research started at CERN at CSU during the academic year.

 

At CERN, our research group has taken on shared responsibilities and duties that have contributed to the success of the ALICE experiment by performing shifts, data analysis, detector maintenance, detector calibrations, technical reviews reviews. We have been involved in the design, simulation, and prototype testing of the Fast Interacting Trigger (FIT) T0-Plus detector, which is an upgrade of the existing T0 detector in ALICE. We have studied the performance of the recently installed di-jet calorimeter (DCal) in simulations, and we are involved in two physics analysis topics. Our group proposed the study of the topology of the jets associated with the J/y decay, as a means to understand the production mechanisms of the J/y prompt and jet quenching in Pb-Pb collisions. In addition, we began an investigation of the production of strange particles in jets.

 

As a result of the support provided by this grant along with others, Chicago State University has been very fortunate that over the last seven summers beginning in the summer of 2010, twenty of its students have had the opportunity to work with the ALICE experiment at CERN. This research and education program provides students with the opportunity to collaborate with R1 universities and research laboratories. They participate in a state of the art research program which engages them in physics analysis and hardware projects through which they have gained valuable experience and professional relationships. A large majorityof the students have presented their work at national conferences. All have found the experience at the LHC to be tremendously rewarding and one that stimulated a strong desire to continue their pursuit of careers in STEM.   A large number of the students are actively pursuing careers in STEM related fields. Since the summer of 2013, the period of this grant, our group has involved thirteen students in research with twelve of them coming from traditionally underrepresented groups. Of the twelve students: three are in physics graduate school, two are in engineering graduate school, one is in math graduate school, one is a physics undergraduate, two are engineering undergraduates and one is a high school physics teacher.

 

In summary, this grant has provided undergraduate students pursuing STEM careers the opportunity to play a role in the application and development of “state of the art” scientific techniques and technology.  In addition, they have had the opportunity to contribute to a major research project having global significance.
